item.title: Dune: Awakening patch ends the reign of vehicular terror, as ramming into other players no longer deals damage
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/dune-awakening-patch-ends-the-reign-of-vehicular-terror-as-ramming-into-other-players-no-longer-deals-damage

Today's Dune: Awakening patch has removed the ability to damage other players in PvP by ramming them with your vehicle, killing the popular PvP tactic.

Tactic is perhaps too strong a word. Hordes of players in Dune: Awakening's Deep Desert end game zone were tracking solos down in orniphopters. If they found them in an orniphopter of their own, they'd shoot them down with missiles.

The real problem emerged if they were on foot. Prior to the patch, if you were hit by a orniphopter you'd be knocked down into a revive state. These pilots then waited for you to self-revive, then crushed you again, leading to a loop of roadkillification.

This trend didn't go down particularly well, with creative director Joel Bylos popping onto Reddit to say the team were working on a fix. This appears to be that fix, and it's going down well among the community. Ciyeelo on Reddit responded with: "Thank fucking god because so-called beta testers Guild with ðŸ¤“ 10k hours of game play was abusing this Day 3 of the early release."

Others still desired additional changes. A popular sentiment is that the vehicles themselves should take damage when taking major bumps. As Illustrious-Hawk-898 puts it: "Being able to ride a buggy off the rim of the Hagga Rift to the bottom, and not taking damage; or flying a thopter into a wall at 160km are some of the most immersion breaking aspects of this game".

So what does this mean for the future of Dune: Awakening? Well, big groups of orniphopter gangs will likely still remain a powerful threat. Even if they can't ram you, five of them rushing you all at once is a little insurmountable. However this change should allow players to line up shots with Lasguns and Rocket Launchers a little easier, especially once more players get their hands on the tier six materials required to create them.

These twists and turns are to be expected in a large PvP setting like the one present in Dune: Awakening's end game. If it sounds like something you're interested in, why not check out Eurogamer's Dune: Awakening review! It covers the end game, describing it as a "weekly political boxing match that I've found endlessly captivating".

item.title: A major Battlefield reveal still set for summer, as Mass Effect bundle takes fans by surprise
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/a-major-battlefield-reveal-still-set-for-summer-as-mass-effect-bundle-takes-fans-by-surprise

The anticipation is massive.

Battlefield 2042 is getting a Mass Effect bundle, as a series exec has confirmed there's still a big Battlefield (2025) reveal set to come this summer.

This Mass Effect bundle comes with various N7-themed skins for both specialists and weapons, with a "Citadel Bundle" containing all Mass Effect cosmetics for 3,000 Battlefield Currency. This comes to roughly Â£22.50 / $25 in value, though you'd have to buy 2,400 and 1,100 BFC separately.

A few days ahead of the bundle's reveal, Battlefield Studios' Global Senior Director of Integrated Comms Andy McNamara responded to a fan on Twitter to say the team has "some things brewing", suggesting a reveal of a new game was on the way. Then, following the announcement of the Mass Effect bundle, McNamara posted: "The community will know when the reveal is coming. We are focused on Labs and preparing for the reveal this summer".

So there's still something to look forward to in the next month or so. We first learned of this summer reveal back in May, as a proper showcase of what the game will look and play like has yet to be produced by the company. The actual name of this new Battlefield is yet to be revealed, an indicator of how much of a mystery the game remains. There have been a series of invite-only playtests, though information from those has leaked online.

In response, EA stated that "things taking place in Labs may or may not make their way to the final" game as it cracked down on leakers. Aside from that, all we know is EA is still aiming to release the game before April 2026.

One would assume that Summer Game Fest would have been a good time to show off this new Battlefield in earnest, but it appears EA is comfortable taking its time with the game still cooking in the oven. Its absence did however allow Call of Duty to take the spotlight somewhat, thanks to Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 wrapping up the Xbox showcase.
